properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain likely tonight. A slow moving cold front will bring a wintry mix of rain and snow today. In the transition zone between the rain and snow, freezing rain is expected to develop this evening. This freezing rain is likely to last for several hours before changing to snow overnight or early Friday morning. Ice accretion or build up is most likely on elevated surfaces however highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T01:17:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-02T09:18:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3138883124.2020
Area: Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson, Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 20 to 30 centimetres of snow are expected between this evening and Friday morning. Moderate to strong winds combined with snow will create some local blowing snow. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T18:23:58-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front continues to spread snow across the northeastern grainbelt. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are likely with this system, although local amounts could be higher. The snow will taper off from south to north throughout the evening into the early overnight hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain Thursday into Friday. A strong low pressure system is forecast to track northward out of the Dakotas on Thursday. The track of this low is uncertain at this time, however it does have the potential to bring significant rain and wet, heavy snow to portions of Northwestern and Far Northwestern Ontario. Current indications suggest that precipitation will begin near Lake of the Woods overnight tonight as a mix of rain and snow. The wintry mix will spread north and eastward on Thursday, giving areas from Ear Falls to Quetico Provincial Park up to 10 mm of rain by Friday morning. Precipitation on Friday may bring an additional 20 mm of rain and 5 cm of snow. Periods of freezing rain will begin near Lake of the Woods Thursday evening along the transition zone between rain and snow and will progress eastward toward Atikokan through Friday. Nothing more than a light glaze of freezing rain is expected at this time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T18:35:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-02T02:36:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0508886441.2020
Area: Ear Falls - Perrault Falls - Western Lac Seul, Dryden - Vermilion Bay, Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River, Seine River Village - Mine Centre
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged Wreckhouse winds expected. Strongest gusts: southeasterly near 100 km/h. Time span: continuing until this afternoon. Remarks: The wind direction will become more northeasterly this afternoon which is less favourable for enhanced Wreckhouse winds. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h and falling snow are producing blizzard conditions in Rankin Inlet. Blizzard conditions will gradually diminish overnight, however blowing snow and near blizzard conditions are expected to develop once again on Thursday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T13:59:17-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front tracking across western Manitoba is bringing heavy wet snow to the region. Current indications are that 10 to 20 cm will fall with this system, although local amounts could be higher. The snow will taper off over the northern Parklands area later this evening. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving low pressure trough will give snow to Manitoba over the next couple of days. In the Red River Valley and Interlake, freezing drizzle will transition to snow this morning, with up to 10 cm today followed by another 5 to 10 cm tonight and a few more on Friday. In southeastern Manitoba near the Ontario border, precipitation will fall mainly as rain today, but freezing rain is likely for several hours tonight before transitioning to snow. Snow will continue all day Friday with totals of 10 to 20 cm. Snow will push northward from Norway House to Thompson, Brochet, and Tadoule Lake today, lingering through Friday and into Saturday as it gradually shifts towards Island Lake, Gillam, Shamattawa and Churchill. Snowfall warnings may also be required for these latter communities at some point in the next day or two. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are likely east of the Red River Valley and through central and northern Manitoba. Amounts will taper down as you go west from the Red River with little in the way of new snow forecast for Brandon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-03T01:28:17-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front tracking across southern Manitoba will spread snow across south central and eastern Manitoba Thursday into Friday. Precipitation will begin as rain this evening but gradually change over to snow across the Red River valley and Interlake tonight and eastern Manitoba on Thursday. At this time the heaviest snowfall amounts are expected east of Winnipeg where totals of 10 to 25 cm are possible. Over the western portions of the Red River Valley and Interlake, including the City of Winnipeg, lesser amounts are expected with totals in the 5 to 15 cm range. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T12:28:24-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. A total of 25 to 45 millimetres of rain is expected by Thursday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Time span: today and this evening, ending late overnight. ### Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry mix of snow and rain Thursday into Friday. A strong low pressure system is forecast to track northward out of the Dakotas on Thursday. The track of this low is uncertain at this time, however it does have the potential to spread heavy wet snow over portions of Northwestern and Far Northwestern Ontario, along the Ontario-Manitoba border. Current indications suggest that precipitation will begin near Lake of the Woods overnight tonight as a mix of rain and snow. The wintry mix will spread north and eastward on Thursday, with areas along the Ontario-Manitoba border most likely to receive snow and areas farther east more likely to receive rain. Snowfall amounts of 5 cm are likely along the Ontario-Manitoba border by Friday morning, with an additional 5 to 10 cm possible on Friday. Periods of freezing rain will begin near Lake of the Woods Thursday evening along the transition zone between rain and snow and will progress eastward toward Atikokan through Friday. Nothing more than a light glaze of freezing rain is expected at this time. A separate Special Weather Statement has been issued for the areas expected to receive a larger proportion of the precipitation as rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T18:33:56-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Another low pressure system will begin to bring snow to east central Saskatchewan tonight and through Thursday. In total, 15 to 25 cm is expected with locally higher amounts possible. Areas east of La Ronge will see the higher snowfall amounts in the region rather than the townsite itself. Snow will begin to taper off Thursday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front tracking across western Manitoba is bringing heavy wet snow to the region. Current indications are that 10 to 20 cm will fall with this system, although local amounts could be higher. The snow will taper off over the southern Parklands area this evening and the northern Parklands area overnight. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T10:59:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T20:27:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1132648490.2020

Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front tracking across western Manitoba is bringing heavy wet snow to the region. Current indications are that 10 to 20 cm will fall with this system, although local amounts could be higher. The snow will taper off over the northern Parklands area later this evening. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
